Roses 2023 and Student Wellbeing

22/04/2023

Emily Warner (she/her) reminds us of the importance of looking after yourself this Roses Weekend

Image by Annie Watson

By Orla McAndrew

We see sport and exercise constantly lauded as a source of mental wellbeing, endorphins, camaraderie and belonging. University sport brings to mind smiling students, slapping each other on the back after a big win or huddling together before a match, a symbol of teamwork and togetherness. York Universityâ€™s Sport and Fitness webpage is no exception, inviting students to;

â€œIndulge your passions or try something new. From beginner to high performer, there is something for everyone at York. At York, sport is all about having fun, being social and giving everyone the opportunity to get involved.Sport and physical activity has a massive role to play in improving the health and wellbeing of our entire university community â€¦ which forges a sense of belonging and inclusion within all sporting and physical wellbeing activities, whatever an individualâ€™s circumstances, capabilities or aspirations.â€

Who wouldnâ€™t want to be a part of that?



It is true that sports are highly beneficial in a number of ways. There are the obvious advantages of staying fit, keeping your body healthy and maintaining strength and agility which will serve students throughout their lives. In addition, getting involved in sport as a student helps you make friends. It can push people outside of their comfort zone, perhaps encourage them to try something new and balance academic studies with something fun. However, with sport comes competition, and this can rapidly teeter over into intense pressure and stress.



Several professional athletes have spoken out about the mental strain of competitive sport such as Naomi Osaka, Michael Phelps, Ronda Rousey, DeMar DeRozan, Justin Duscherer and many others. Although their struggles are deeply personal, there is also a shared narrative between them; their profession as athletes has made their struggle somehow less recognised. Duscherer told Menâ€™s Journal in 2011, â€œmy problem is Iâ€™m a soft guy in a profession of hard guysâ€ and DeMar DeRozan tweeted, â€œNo matter how indestructible we look like we are, we're all human at the end of the dayâ€. What these comments have shown is that athletes are people too. They are more than physical beings to be honed for performance and then brutally commented on by the press and by fans; their emotional wellbeing can be bruised as easily as anyone else.



This is no different for those competing as students, within a university. In fact, student athletes may be at more risk of mental health issues for a range of reasons. Pressure to meet academic deadlines alongside sport commitments can be overwhelming (imagine training for an important race with three essays due that week). University is also a significant transition period in most peopleâ€™s lives, which can lead to a worsening of psychological disorders; most students would tell you theyâ€™re constantly in the midst of an existential crisis. There is a constant pressure to conform amongst young people. The way you look, the way you act and the â€˜groupâ€™ youâ€™re part of are all vital to the student experience, and can be devastating for those who donâ€™t feel like they â€˜fit inâ€™.



On the flipside, for some students, being an athlete is a large part of their identity, and obstacles to their training (injury, work, assessments) can lead to significant emotional distress.



This side of sport is often hidden behind the label, â€˜mental toughnessâ€™, the damaging concept that competitive sport is about endurance, powering through and silence in the face of struggle. Acknowledging mental health problems is frequently and erroneously attributed to weakness. However, taking care of yourself emotionally, often requires as much resilience and effort as the physical aspect of playing sport. Mental wellbeing is an important area of consideration for Roses 2023, alongside the more typical discussions about nutrition, skill, training and strategy. Thereâ€™s no point running fast if youâ€™re crippled by the pressure of spectators, or perfecting your technique if an eating disorder is preventing you from fuelling your body. The mental and physical are intertwined, and neglect of the former will lead to an inevitable decline in the latter.



This year, Roses is running a campaign called â€˜The Roses Loungeâ€™ to tackle this problem. This will be a relaxing space, run by a team of supporting advisors and volunteers, away from the commotion of the sporting events. It will allow teams to reconvene, chat, re-energise and take some vital time out. Most importantly, it demonstrates to participants that itâ€™s okay not to be okay.



So, amidst the excitement of Roses, make sure to take care of yourself. Donâ€™t be swept up by the expectations of others, the stress of competing and the pressure to perform. Roses is about having fun.
